After 1 month of IOS 18 update I got this issue.

Two days ago, my iPhone 14 Pro Max suddenly died; it is unresponsive to any software combination or action, rendering it completely inert. There was no prior damage, and there was no reason for this to occur. Despite this, I encountered this issue and found numerous similar complaints on YouTube. I have invested a significant amount of money in attempts to resolve the problem, yet it remains unresolved. Unfortunately, there is no Apple Care service available in Nepal for me to seek assistance.

I have heard that this issue may be related to the introduction of new Apple products to the market, but it should be Apple's responsibility to rectify the matter, not the consumer's. I have not mishandled my phone; it was not overcharged, and I have never even used a power bank. Despite these precautions, I am facing this problem. Therefore, I urge you to find a solution promptly, or the possibility of legal action against Apple may need to be considered.

This situation is particularly distressing as the money spent on this device was hard-earned. We choose to purchase Apple products due to their reliability and reputation, but my experience has proven otherwise.

Yes Apple absolutely loves small / thin appliances, this has been a Jobs guideline since his return in 1997. This can be seen in many decisions, he led the way on USB-A adoption on Macs, he worked to eliminate the analog audio jack on iPhones, the iPad is as thin as possible, so it's no surprise this design goal also shows up on the Mac Mini.

Power button on the bottom: inconsequential. This is intended as an always-on device, and even when you are taking it with you, when you unpack it you have to pick it up, plug it in, and you have access to the power button at that time. If you forget where the power button is on the thing and you regularly use it, then you don't use the button often enough, so this is an irrelevant criticism. It's out of the way because doesn't need to be in the way.

Apple's design decisions for products like the Magic Mouse and Mac mini have long been the subject of debate. Despite years of feedback, the Magic Mouse's charging port is still located on the bottom, which prevents it from being used while charging. The power button on the new Mac mini 4 is also located on the bottom, requiring the user to lift the device to turn it on. These decisions beg the question ‚ÄúDid Apple's design team ever consider alternative placements?‚Äù

At the core of Apple's design philosophy is a simple principle ‚Äùif a feature is not frequently used, it does not need to be emphasised‚Äù. This approach explains why aesthetic considerations are often more important than functional ones, with form taking priority over usability. This is a valuable lesson for designers, because sometimes developing elegant, visually consistent products means that certain functions have to take a back seat.

A closer look at user behavior confirms Apple's stance. The Magic Mouse can be used for about a month on a 2-hour charge, so it doesn't need to be constantly recharged. The power button is also rarely used by Mac mini users, so its placement is less critical.

Apple's approach challenges designers to question traditional priorities. Sometimes the design decisions we make are not even based on user research, but on an aesthetic vision to create a seamless, minimalist experience.

The M4 Mac Mini is small, but its size isn't revolutionary.
Plenty of MiniPCs (e.g. GMKTec K6) have exactly the same 5''x5''x2'' dimensions. The K6 also costs half as much as the M4 Mac Mini, with twice as much RAM and SSD capacity, and its Ryzen 7 7840HS CPU is overall about the same speed as the M4 10-core. The M4's iGPU is nearly twice as fast though, and it uses less than half as much power, so the M4 Mac Mini is still a pretty good computer for its price.

3:31 whenever you spoke about why you thought they placed the charge port for the magic mouse on the bottom of the device, you would say something along the lines that it was because whenever people take pictures of their computers, it would make the desk look cleaner because otherwise people would just keep the mouse plugged in at all times, meaning it would be attached to a wire, and Apple is trying to get rid of wires as part of their "image" or something of that nature, so it was more of a marketing thing to some extent. 

I think this is no different with the power button. Apple likely put it on the bottom of the Mac Mini not only for aesthetic appeal to the average person, who may not care about design, but to keep the brand front and center for anyone passing by your desk. A power button isn't exactly stylish, so it was previously placed on the back of the Mac Mini. However, they know that with the button in the back, the Mac Mini itself tends to be pushed to the back of the desk or even hidden. I believe Apple wants the Mac Mini front and center‚Äînot only as a constant reminder of their brand but also to encourage you to keep it on your desk where it‚Äôs easily accessible for daily use. Lastly, by placing the power button on the bottom, they make sure you interact with the device frequently, which keeps you aware of how compact and powerful it truly is. In a way, it‚Äôs a subtle design choice to remind you each time you pick it up just how much performance is packed into such a small, lightweight package.

I think the last notion is probably the truest out of all three, simply because I remember when Steve Jobs demonstrated one of the early iPad generations‚Äîand through several iterations after the first one, they kept using the word "magical." Even to this day, I look back at technology and how far it‚Äôs come over the past few decades, and it‚Äôs no small feat to go from a large CRT monitor connected to a massive tower that could only handle basic functions, to a sleek, lightweight device more powerful than the computers used for Apollo 11. That word "magical" still resonates with me, and I often think, "God, this truly is magical," every time I pick up an iPad. I can imagine feeling the same way every time I pick up the Mac Mini, reminded that this tiny, powerful device is packed to the gills with incredible performance in such a compact form.

It‚Äôs literally more expensive to double the RAM and storage than to buy two complete units. I guess the M4, case, power supply, cooling system, etc are all free? Upgrade pricing is just absurd.

Unfortunately, you can‚Äôt combine the RAM and storage from two units into anything equivalent to a 32GB/512GB unit. For some purposes, the two separate machines would be better, but for others, you need all that in one unit.

I think I'd mount it on the wall, bottom out. It would also make it easier to access the front and back ports when un/plugging peripherals.

‚ÄúWiping RAM‚Äù should not be necessary in most cases. I run a Mac mini for literally months at a time (often sleeping, so not gulping power), and watching memory usage, macOS is pretty good about purging stale RAM over time. Maybe there will be a lot of purgeable and swap, but if I come back after a day or two it‚Äôs been cleaned out automatically. This is also why I can run my MacBook Pro for work for roughly a month at a time; even though I run graphics apps, the dynamic memory management means if I need to restart the Mac, it‚Äôs rarely because of a reason related to RAM. Usually it‚Äôs because a software update requires a restart.

@ everybody says that and has been saying that for years, but it‚Äôs not entirely true. Many apps and processes still leave behind junk in RAM, especially when they crash, and MacOS deliberately parks what it deems to be frequently used or recently used data in RAM for faster access later. The issue occurs when you need a big chunk freed up for better performance,and there‚Äôs no way to clean the slate manually. Personally I use a memory cleaner app for those cases, and only rarely, yet nice to have the option. As for users who aren‚Äôt aware of that option, a restart may be fine.

If you can stomach Apple! I've been a software consultant for 50 years for Intel, AT&T, Bell Labs, Mayo Clinic, Amtrak and half the banks & investment houses on Wall Street. In that entire time, I've worked on scores of computers & operating systems from the old IBM 360/370, through MS DOS, Windows, UNIX, OS/2, Sun 3/50 through Solaris, HP-UX, a dozen Linux distos (I'm writing this on Kali Linux running on an $80 Raspberry Pi 5 credit-card-sized computer with 2 43" UHDTV monitors, a 2 TB M.2 SSD "hat" on the card's PCIe connector , wifi, ethernet, bluetooth, 2 camera connectors & a full set of GPIO pins). I have another Pi 5 also running Kali with a 2-lithium-battery power "hat," a "power-over-ethernet" hat  for use in offices, a power wall-wart, and a 1080p 7" touchscreen. I can put it all in a waist pack & go portable. I've got a dozen different models of Raspberry Pis doing everything from providing my own home security with infrared detectors & cameras, functioning as a Pwnagotchi & acting as a secondary router that sits between my ISP-provided router & my intranet, blocking the ISP's backdoor into their router & running NordVPN for the entire intranet.

My new primary tower came with Windows 11 2H24 installed, but I changed the bios setting to boot from a thumb drive to install Ubuntu 24-04 (soon to upgrade to 24-10), which totally wiped the C: drive before installing Ubuntu. Windows never even booted up before it was gone! I now have 3 2-TB SSDs & a 2-TB spinner disk in the machine & 60 TB of external drives in a NAS set at RAID 1+0 for data integrity, a 14th generation Core i9 14900K chip with 24 cores running at 6GHz,  upgraded to 128 GB RAM & put in a gaming-style video card with a monster GPU & 3 cooling fans. I have an upgraded WiFi PCIe board that includes the newest Bluetooth & WiFi 6E that goes in today. Beat THAT, Mac. My Wife's laptop has Windows 11 (last year's version - we won't upgrade) because I can't convince her to learn even the Windows-friendly versions of Linux. The one computer I've never seen any professional developer using in all these years is a Mac (that's not entirely true - one friend's laptop was in the shop so he borrowed his son's Mac laptop, put a virtual machine on it & ran Windows in it to write & run his code). Only the art departments sometimes used Macs - because they are mostly artistic, but computer illiterate. They are way overpriced & inferior to too many other good systems at far cheaper prices. Apple has everything built in China & now Vietnam. When you buy one of their $600 phones for $1200 (everything is 50% profit), the money goes to a tax haven in Ireland, where they pay 2% tax to Ireland. Whenever a Republican gets into the White House, he declares a "tax holiday" and Apple moves a bunch of untaxed profit into the US. They have no allegiance to the US and pay NO federal corporate taxes, despite being worth $3 TRILLION. I knew the #3 Apple person who was in charge of designing the Mac desktop (stolen from a prototype done by Xerox Palo Alto Research Center in the late 70s - Jobs took a tour & said, "That's the future of Apple as soon as we can do it & not get sued"). He told me that Jobs had such contempt for his own customers that when they were meeting to discuss using a 2-button mouse or a 3-button mouse like Sun uses, Jobs jumped up, slammed his fist on the table & said 'We are designing this computer for the sort of person who would have trouble telling right from left. We go with a 1-button mouse." He even had contempt for the people who made him a billionaire. 

Macs DO make excellent expensive "designer" door-stops, you can skip an iPad across a lake for at least 5 hops, & iPhones make decent sinkers for deep-sea fishing, though. One ex-Mac creator from one of the original hardware development teams told me recently that, if he was crawling across a desert dying of thirst & came upon a new iPhone with a 5 bar signal and a full charge, he'd keep on crawling to his death rather than use it. Get Intel or AMD computers & run Linux Mint if you want an easy distro of Linux you can set up similarly to MacOS and Windows.

I would buy a 256 Gb M1 Mac Mini in preference to a 256 Gb M2 Mac Mini. This is because The SSD in the 256 Gb M1 Mac Mini consists of two 128 Gb flash modules, whereas the SSD in the M2 Mac Mini consists of only one 256 Gb Gb flash module which is half as fast as two modules.

This leads to the most important question about the 256 Gb M4 Mac Mini. Does the 256 Gb M4 Mac Mini have two 128 Gb flash modules or only one 256 Gb Flash module?  If the ¬£599 M4 model has two modules then it is a very good buy. Otherwise the 512 Gb ¬£799 M4 model is the only sensible choice.

I watched "2024 M4 Mac Mini Teardown" by "Brandon Geekabit" and it reveals that the flash memory is located on a removable daughter board resembling the standard M.2 2230 flash memory board in a Steam Deck. Superficially it looks as if this daughter board is a standard part but I suspect that Apple has modified this board to have a proprietary design to make user upgrades impossible.

3:04 I think they add small, intentionally inconvenient features to deter users from using the device in ways that could harm its longevity. These minor annoyances help prevent some seemingly logical choices that customers are willing to gamble with. 

ie; because the Mac Mini is so compact, people might place it in poorly ventilated spaces, like small cubbies or tight desk compartments, which could increase heat and reduce the lifespan of its components. Putting the button on the back and bottom makes the idea of placing the mac mini in the above situation a pain to handle, so the user likely to choose a scenario better for Apple and the user

I see all Apple devices and software have lots of these guard rails. They don't demand you use it a specific way but do enough to curtail you in a direction, that to be honest, if you follow is beneficial and is in your best interest, which is kind of rare for giant companies like this.

I think this review would have benefited a lot from a comparison to, say, a Beelink SER9. That's almost identical in form factor, but uses an AMD HX370 chip. It's cheaper, at around $1k for 32gb RAM and 1tb of SSD, but probably not as powerful as the M4. Geekbench measures for the Hx370 are all over the map, and it comes in a number of different TDP varieties, so you'd have to actually run the tests to get good numbers, but it looks like it might perform closer to an M2 in terms of CPU, but pretty close to an M4 in terms of GPU. But that's speculation. All I'm really saying is that this form factor is actually pretty common now in mini PCs (Minisforum makes similar machines too) and it would help convey your point that this is much more powerful if we had another reference point for comparing those numbers besides more macs. I know the folks who always buy macs mostly only care about macs, but there's more interest in the mac hardware this time around from those of us who don't usually use macs, both because Windows has been screwing around lately and because the Mac hardware has proven really good at AI stuff. Switching to Mac doesn't seem a whole lot more unreasonable than switching to Linux. (And I'd even regain access to Fusion 360.)

Anyway, thanks for your review. It's still all a little pricey for my tastes, but I really do like that computers are getting so small and powerful.

I'm sorry, but the affordability factor is fake. It's my biggest gripe with Apple, and the reason why I still can't commit to their computer system. They cripple their base level offerings with stupidly small storage and make that the "entry" build and then charge through the nose for more storage and memory. That way they can give the appearance of affordability because, sure, you can technically own one for cheap, but it will have the storage capacity of a device from 15 years ago. Storage is cheap now. Like, stupidly cheap. Apple wants to charge $200 to "upgrade" from 256GB to 512GB... I mean come on... At retail - RETAIL - you can buy 256GB of M.2 storage for less than $30 and 1TB for less than $60 (and you know Apple's cost for parts doesn't come anywhere near retail). For the $700 you would spend to get this with 512GB of storage, you could build one of those mini PCs with 2TB of storage, an i7 processor, and 64GB or memory. And they do this because they don't want people to actually buy the cheaper models - they are just there to artificially justify the higher priced builds.
At this point they might as well just make a phone with a way to connect to a monitor with a desktop UI. After all, you have your phone with you no matter what.

Like, USB-C HP laptops that businesses now use, having them connected via USB-C to a USB-C monitor, with the USB-C monitor providing power to the laptop... you never even need to open the laptop... So... can Mac Mini also do this? 

It also brings to mind another question: Why does Mac Mini even need a dedicated power cable, when obviously Apple could implement Power Delivery, to have the Mac powered by the connected display. wouldn't the display you're gonna use it with need AC?

USB-C isn't designed for that. It doesn't sit securely enough into the socket to be reliable and it's susceptible to more fluctuations in power delivery. It doesn't matter on things like laptops and phones because they have a battery as the buffer.

Plus that's then a permanently dedicated USB-C port being used exclusively for power. It's not like a laptop where you can just unplug it and still use it with something else while it runs on battery.

Most solar power banks have AC outlets by the way, unless you mean those tiny portable ones.
Fair point - you could use an inverter if you wanted to?

I have a Mac Mini M1, and it's an ok deal, but it's not as outstanding as he's making it out to be. 

A lot of the accessories you already have won't work with it (unless you find a workaround). There's no upgradability. The GPU is weak. So many productivity apps aren't available. Gaming on it sucks. 

Instead of making this version smaller, I wish they'd of put a card reader on the front, 1TB base storage, and put a batter inside of it so we could use it mobile.

Next Unit of Computing (NUC) is a line of small-form-factor barebone computer kits designed by Intel. Previewed in 2012 and launched in early 2013,[1] the NUC line continues to develop over generations of Intel-based CPU launches, spanning from Sandy Bridge-based Celeron CPUs in the first generation, to Raptor Lake-based mobile and desktop CPUs in the thirteenth, and more recently Meteor Lake-based processors with AI capabilities.[2]
he standard barebone kits consist of the NUC board, in a plastic case with a fan, an external power supply, and a VESA mounting plate.[3] The plastic case is typically offered on one of two chassis, Tall (allowing for a 2.5" drive bay) or Slim (no 2.5" drive bay).[4] The NUC motherboard measures approximately 10 √ó 10 centimetres (4 √ó 4 in),[5] although some models have had different dimensions. Intel also sells bare NUC motherboards, which have a built-in CPU.

Apple does a great job at designing that price ladder.  IMO users really *need* to increase the SSD to 512-GB.  After that, if they need a lot of disk space then it's probably better (although not as convenient or pretty) to go with an external disk.
In my case I went pretty far up the ladder.  I still have a Mac Pro running from 2012 (as well as a Mac Mini from 2018), so I view this purchase as something I want to be happy with for at least five years.  Maybe even ten.  Do I need the faster memory-bandwidth of the M4 Pro chip?  Not really, but it'd be nice to *have* that for all of the next five-six years.  And as you say, every time the customer talks themself into one step up the ladder, then the next step up is pretty tantalizing.

One angle on the tiny footprint is data center usage of Macs. Apple requires physical hardware in their license to run macOS, and limits macOS VMs to 2 per machine. So, if you have some workload that needs to run in the cloud you need actual Mac hardware. This will allow vendors like AWS to cram even more hardware into the same amount of space.

About Apple computer pricing, Apple has historically priced their computers very high because it always sold something that no-one else was selling.   In the 1980s, it was the only one with a graphical interface.   Apple knew that if you did not want to use a computer typing command line, you would pay the premium Apple wanted to charge.   You can find many Apple internal documents where Apple specifically decided and knew that they could charge more than IBM compatibles.   Many  times Apple engineers wanted to build cheaper Mac to increase the market share, but management would artificially keep the prices high because they knew people would pay for that special thing that Apple exclusively had.   Then Windows became a good graphical interface and Apple struggled for a long time, until Steve Jobs made Apple cool and for a while that was the unique Apple thing that people paid a premium for.   Now, Apple has the most efficient SoC, delivering the fastest computers at the lowest voltage/longest battery life.   With the M4, Apple keeps up this long tradition of offering something that no-one else is offering, so if people want the top CPU, they will pay the Apple tax to get it.   But instead of just pricing Macs very high like before, the new thing that Apple is doing now is to price an entry level Mac at a very attractive "Low" price, but making sure that the entry level computers do not have enough RAM and SSD, and then charging you an arm and a leg to upgrade the entry level Mac to an usable level at a very high price.    So for example, Apple actually wants to sell you a Mac Mini for $1799, even though a comparable Windows PC is just $800.    So instead of pricing it at $1799, Apple makes an entry level Mac Mini priced at $599, but intentionally with low 8GB RAM (until recently, now 16GB RAM) and a very small 256GB SSD (still).    The unsuspecting buyer sees the $599 price, then when the buyer upgrades the RAM and SSD to something that he/she wants (like 32GB RAM, 2TB SSD), Apple charges $400 for the additional 16GB RAM and $800 for the additional 1792GB of SSD storage, so the buyer ends up paying the $1799 Apple originally wanted to charge.   To make this work, Apple designed the tech from the ground up so that you can upgrade RAM and SSD only from Apple by designing the RAM and SSD "soldered" into the SoC,  even when Windows computers with upgradable/removable RAM and SSD modules have shown to be actually faster than Apple's all-in-SoC design.    Apple has to build the tech from the ground up this way to have a plausible technical argument against the regulators, should the regulators complain that consumers have no choice to upgrade anywhere else.   It is amazing how Apple has become the richest company in the world by making something everyone wants, then designing a scheme so that they can charge a premium/Apple tax, escaping the regular market forces of competition so that they can make huge profits.    This way, Apple is double assured to make a huge profit, first by making products people want, then second by designing away the competition so that the technology does not work unless you upgrade only from Apple.    (PS: At least now, people can buy a Mac for $599, a bit crippled with just 256GB SSD, but at least you are not locked out completely from an Apple computer like people were, like back in the 1980s - 2000s, when people could not pay the Apple asking high price of $1799.   So I guess this is progress? It‚Äôs really disappointing to hear the comment at 3:30. 

Marques, of all people, should appreciate why Apple might‚Äôve chosen to place the button there‚Äîconsidering their dedication to design.

For such a small device, placing the button anywhere else makes it nearly impossible to turn on *with one hand*. Put it in the front, and you‚Äôd have to hold the device with the other hand or twist awkwardly to press it. Place it on top, and you risk accidental pushes that could turn it off or put it to sleep unintentionally.

The bottom is the only logical, ergonomic, and safe spot. You can turn it on with one hand by simply pinching the device.

Think back to when Apple first put the iMac‚Äôs power button on the lower back‚Äîit was for the same reason. Any front placement would require an awkward hold or rotating the device.

So, the ‚Äúconspiracy‚Äù here is actually that Apple has an excellent industrial designer who truly cares about human-centered design, much like Dieter Rams did. We‚Äôre fortunate they still take such thoughtful, design-centric approaches.

And regarding the charging port placement on the Magic Mouse‚Äîif you charge it for just 2 minutes, you get 9 hours of battery life.

Go grab a coffee or take a quick break, and it‚Äôs ready to go. With this feature, the location of the charging port is irrelevant because it eliminates the need to keep the mouse connected while using it. The design intentionally bypasses the inconvenience of having it attached to a cable, making the placement a non-issue.

Mac, windows, Linux, your phone, whatever your router/modem runs on, anything that runs some kind of system needs to be at minimum restarted occasionally. A desktop implies that you have onboard expansion or you can swap stuff out -fix.  This is a mobile nuc type device (system on a chip) with everything onboard.  It's a disposable laptop with human input and output not included.  It is a reasonable price though for average users and very solid performance.

No, you're confusing "desktop" with "tower".

Laptop literally means "lap top", a computer made to be mobile and that can be used everywhere, even on your lap. It has a built-in display, battery, keyboard and mouse pointing device.

Desktop literally means "desk top", a computer made to be used on a desk in a fixed setup. It has no built-in display or battery and usually has no input devices, although "keyboard computers" (like the old Commodore 64) are partially coming back, such as the Raspberry Pi 400.

I have a theory on one of Apple's main reasons for the power button on the bottom. Tactility. When the original iMac was designed, Johnny Ive was asked (I'm paraphrasing) why it had a handle because it was light enough to carry/move without it (back in 1998 it was pretty small and light for a desktop). He said that by having a handle, just to take it out of the box, gives the end-user a bond with it, a relationship with it, back when computers were still scary for a lot of people. Apple have continued that design philosophy with almost all of their products. The want people to pick them up, touch them, look at them from all angles. I wouldn't be at all surprised if that is why the Apple mouse charger is on the bottom. Ok, maybe not not the mouse! üòÖ

I think the power button under the Mac is like a message that is so power efficient that you don‚Äôt need to turn it off/on, just leave it on like MacBooks. 

And that‚Äôs besides getting everyone to talk about it üòÖ

The power button placement is way overblown and I haven't seen anyone in media yet point out that it likely has a very good reason for its placement.  Ignoring the fact that the old macmini had the button inconveniently at the back, and the fact that most people don't really ever need to cycle power on macs with the power button;  A lot of people mount their mac mini's behind a monitor or under a desk.  These mounts are typically designed with aesthetics in mind such that the Apple Logo is "visible" when mounted... even though the entire point of these mounts is to move the machine out of sight.  With the Older mac min, it was large enough that air could still circulate, but mounts still caused circulation issues.  With this one,  Putting it inside a mount fans down will suffocate it.   This way, mount designers are compelled to design mounts that require fans to be facing out in order to have an accessible power button.

The baseline model is great value for money, but I wouldn't go as far to say that this Mac Mini is unmatched as said at 2:45 . There are tiny pc's, just as small or within a few centimetes left or right, that perform similarly. You have things like the Beelink SER9 which is in a similar performance class, or one of the many Minisforum tiny pc's. Those have (as far as I know off) yet to be upgraded with the latest generation AMD Ryzen CPU's (which are already in that Beelink), but both are options.
Still, the Mac Mini is a great value, but so are some of the others.

The Mac mini will be more thermal efficient than any of those options. It's just the way ARM-based architecture works. It runs cooler, faster and more efficiently because the whole computer is on a single chip. Also, Mac build quality trumps your listed options. As someone who mass-deploys Beelink devices as SNMP monitors at their job, I can attest that they have an extremely high failure rate: about 40% within two years. An average lifespan of under two years in the field is pathetic. They're made with generic hardware, the RAM/SSD modules often have Chinese characters written on them and no manufacturer info. Those computers aren't even in the same league as a Mac mini. You get what you pay for.

I think apple putting the power button on the bottom was to inconvenience 3rd party dock manufacturers. Also their way of making you have to grab the Mac mini every time you turn it on that way you develop a connection to the product that‚Äôs more physical.
mac studio is fine

For people with one hand or one arm, having the button there is a good spot. It allows them to pinch with one hand to press it. If it were on the back, their single hand may be too small to squeeze the whole computer in order to press it, and they may not have a convenient solid object to push it against. 

Apple would never put a button on top. It is more susceptible to spills and other physical damage, like the home button of older iphones. 

But really, who cares. Most people will never purposefully turn their mac off. The OS is so stable, it rarely benefits from being restarted.

Reasons to put the button on the bottom:
- If the outer shell is a heatsink; is ANOTHER cutout worth the loss of thermal efficiency? 
- If its so small you can hold and pick it up in a single hand, there's a very likely chance you'll keep pressing the button every time to pick it up
- You're likely to touch the places where it _could_ go when gripping the chassis to insert or eject cables...
- How often do you actually need to use the button? Is it so heavy that picking it up and pressing the button going to be that much of an issue?

I get it; it _seems_ stupid; and yet, I can't think where else it could go... if anything, it's suprising it even exists. Reminds me of not having an eject button and instead putting it on the keyboard...
